sections.subtitle: 1. Print Text
sections.text: You have already learned that you can use the print() function to display text or output values:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print("Hello World!")

You can use the print() function as many times as you want. Each call prints text on a new line by default:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print("Hello World!")
print("I am learning Python."))
print("It is awesome!")

sections.subtitle: Double Quotes
sections.text: Text in Python must be inside quotes. You can use either double quotes or single quotes:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print("This will work!")
print('This will also work!')

If you forget to put the text inside quotes, Python will give an error:

sections.subtitle: Print Without a New Line
sections.text:
By default, the print() function ends with a new line.

If you want to print multiple items on the same line, you can use the end parameter of the print() function:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print("Hello World!", end=" ")
print("I will print on the same line.")

Note that we add a space after end=" " for better readability.

sections.subtitle: 2. Print Numbers
sections.text:
You can also use the print() function to display numbers:
However, unlike text, we don't put numbers inside double quotes:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
print(3)
print(358)
print(50000)
